channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: NLP is all right by me! Perl, Python, NLP role in Amsterdam
item.description: A global leader in machine intelligence matching job seekers with their perfect career: our client’s goal is human level parsing. They’re on the hunt for an NLP Engineer whose passion for NLP is matched only by their interest in Machine Intelligence and their ability to drive quality improvements, measurement standards, and error analysis processes for the NLP framework.

item.title: Let’s get SaaSsy! Remote Perl role within US time zone
item.description: Our client is the world’s leading provider of award-winning intelligent SaaS solutions for clients ranging from first responders and engineers to manufacturers and educators. The successful candidate is a Perl developer with Catalyst and Dblx::Class. You’ve been around the block and you know your stuff.

item.title: Thought-Leader Wanted. Chief Software Architect role in Malaysia
item.description: As Chief Software Architect for an international company providing online trading services, you’ll work closely with the Chief Technology Officer. With a strong understanding of the full stack of software development and cloud technologies, you’ll mentor engineering teams and provide guidance in solving technical issues.

item.title: Music-loving DevOps (with Perl), get in here! London based role
item.description: We’ve got an intriguing role for a Lead DevOps Engineer who cares about great music. Perl experience would be helpful, and knowledge of Linux, configuration management tooling like Ansible or Puppet, and experience operating in a physical data centre are must-haves.

item.title: Perl developers throw a mean party! Remote Perl role in UK and EU
item.description: As the developer and operator of software platforms providing web presence services to guests around the world, our clients take hosting to the next level. You will need strong Perl skills and Linux and/or FreeBSD experience. This role is 100% remote within the UK and EU.

item.title: Boston Perl Mongers Online Meeting - topic TBD or round-table
item.description: Tuesday April 12th, 2021 07:00 PM Eastern Time (US and Canada)

item.title: Show and Tell! (round robin)
item.description: Wednesday, March 30, 2022; 06:00 PM Eastern Time (US and Canada)

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Open Source translator (instead of Google translate)
item.description: I found a neat alternative to Google translate. Now I am trying to figure out how to find enough text in Ladino to be able to add the Ladino translator.

item.title: Three means and big bases
item.description: Welcome back after short break, we missed you and thanks for your contributions ever.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 157: Pythagoras in Brazil
item.description: Liked hack to get one decimal place result. Solution to Brazilian number task is really cool. Keep it up great work,

item.title: Mean Brazilians
item.description: Peter's blog shares the fun behind the solution. It is always pleasure to read the blog. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 157
item.description: Luis master of one-liner, once again came up with Perl one-liner to solve the Pythagorean Means. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 157: numbers
item.description: Cool use Bag feature of Raku makes the solution looks so compact. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 157: Pythagorean Means and Brazilian Number
item.description: I always follow Raku code first then Perl. It makes so easy to follow the code. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: PWC157 - Brazilian Number
item.description: Generalization of Brazilian numbers task is really cool. Worth checking out Thanks for sharing.

item.title: PWC157 - Pythagorean Means
item.description: I loved the re-use of arithmetic mean in the calculation of harmonic mean. You must check ot out. Highly recommended.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 157
item.description: James is known for his compact and scalable solutions. Notes in the blog is really useful to decode the code. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: I Cannot Count To A Brazillian
item.description: Dave's style of frank discussion is always fun. Codes looks poetry to me. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Waxing Numeric
item.description: Talk analysis is the key feature of Colin's blog. For me it is more important than the solution itself. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Pythagoras Was a Meanie
item.description: Behind the scene story of Pythagoras is the highlight for me. One-liner in Perl solution is worth reading. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Brazilian Means with Raku
item.description: Great show of Raku magics as always. Plenty to learn, at least for me. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 153
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 157
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Pythagorean Means" and "Brazilian Number" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 158
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Additive Primes" and "First Series Cuban Primes". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Dancer2: Plackup reload on Windows and Linux
Installing Perl: A Chicken-and-Egg Problem
item.description: Installing Perl from scratch on a Raspberry Pi that lost its mind.

item.description: corkscrew is a handy program to set up SSH connectivity through a web proxy that supports the CONNECT verb.

item.description: This post explains how to implement a simple Perl client/server using TCP sockets

item.title: Local to remote port forwarding with socat
Tricked by __PACKAGE__
item.description: __PACKAGE__ cannot be treated like a sub before perl version 5.16.

item.title: #557 - Human languages
item.description:
Hi there!

First of all, let me congratulate to Mohammad S. Anwar for editing 100 issue of the Perl Weekly. If you visit the main page of the web-site you will see the list of all the editors, past and present, in order as they joined and the number of issues they edited. Let me thank all of you!

Learning programming languages is not easy, but if you compare that to learning human languages you'll notice that it has a lot more difficulties. Human languages have much bigger vocabulary and much bigger grammar with lots of exceptions. This already makes it much harder to learn on, but in addition it is hard to get fast and cheap feedback. Something you are given by the compiler/interpreter of your language. You can even add more by writing your own tests and setting up a CI system. That's part of the value DuoLingo provides. Fast and cheap feedback. However it is propriatery. LibreLingo is an open source alternative to which I started to contribute. The biggest fun part for me is actually trying to write a course - basically building a dictionary and writing sample sentences.

Enjoy your week!
